title-group.article-title: Association between four anthropometric indices with age-related Macular Degeneration from NHANES 2005–2008

contrib-group.aff: https://ror.org/042v6xz23grid.260463.50000 0001 2182 8825Department of Ophthalmology, The First Affiliated Hospital of Nanchang University, Jiangxi Medical College, Nanchang University, Nanchang, Jiangxi People’s Republic of China

sec.title: Background
sec.p: Age-related macular degeneration (AMD) decrease vision and presents considerable challenges for both public health and clinical management strategies. Obesity is usually implicated with increased AMD, and body mass index (BMI) does not reflect body fat distribution. An array of studies has indicated a robust relationship between body fat distribution and obesity. This research is to evaluate the relationship between anthropometric measurements and AMD in the United States citizens in a cohort of patients.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: Our study included a cohort of 3,127 participants, all of whom were selected from the National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES) conducted between 2005 and 2008. Various anthropometric indices, including weight (WT), waist circumference (WC), Body Mass Index (BMI), waist-to-height ratio (WtHR), circularity index (CI), weight-adjusted waist circumference index (WWI), body roundness index (BRI), a body size index (ABSI), and visceral adiposity index (VAI), have been studied extensively within public health and nutrition to assess body fat distribution. Odds ratios (OR) for each anthropometric index, in relation to AMD and its different stages, were computed, adjusting for confounding variables. Smoothed curve fitting, coupled with weighted multivariable logistic regression analysis, was used to examine the impact of these anthropometric measures on the prevalence of AMD. Subgroup analyses were conducted according to gender, age, BMI, drinking, smoking, CVD, diabetes, hypertension, cataract operation, and glaucoma.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: After adjusting for all variables, significant positive correlations were observed between WtHR (OR = 1.237 (1.065−1.438)), BRI (OR = 1.221 (1.058−1.410)), CI (OR = 1.189 (1.039−1.362)), and WWI (OR = 1.250 (1.095−1.425)) with AMD, particularly for early AMD. However, no significant effects of these indicators were observed in late AMD. CI exhibited a positive linear relationship with AMD. Two-segment linear regression modeling revealed positive nonlinear associations between WtHR, BRI, and WWI with AMD. The positive association was more pronounced with excessive alcohol consumption for WtHR, BRI, CI, and WWI (P for interaction = 0.0033, 0.0021, 0.0194, and 0.0022, respectively). Additionally, WWI and CI exhibited stronger associations with AMD in females (P for interaction = 0.0146 and 0.0117, respectively). Furthermore, WtHR was associated with AMD in non-smokers (P for interaction = 0.0402).

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This study confirmed a increased risk between four anthropometric measures, including WtHR, BRI, CI, and WWI, with AMD, especially early AMD. The findings suggest that these four anthropometric indices should be more broadly utilized to improve early AMD prevention and treatment strategies. Additionally, we found that the positive association between these four body measurement indices and AMD was more pronounced in individuals with high alcohol consumption.

sec.title: Supplementary Information
sec.p: The online version contains supplementary material available at 10.1186/s12944-024-02424-2.

kwd-group.title: Keywords
kwd-group.kwd: National health and nutrition examination survey

custom-meta.meta-value: © BioMed Central Ltd., part of Springer Nature 2025

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: As a common neurodegenerative eye condition, AMD primarily affects older adults and has become the third most common contributor to vision loss globally [1]. By 2020, the global population with AMD was estimated to be around 196 million, with projections suggesting an increase to 288 million by 2040 [2, 3]. If the disease cannot be effectively prevented, affected individuals will continue to suffer, resulting in a substantial socio-economic burden. Although anti-vascular endothelial growth factor treatments provide some benefits for patients with wet AMD, effective medications for the majority of AMD cases remain unavailable. Therefore, identifying modifiable risk factors is crucial for preventing and managing this disease [4].

The onset of AMD is influenced by an interplay of environmental and genetic factors [5]. The risk determinants associated with the deposition of drusen, a hallmark of AMD, are similar to atherosclerosis, suggesting that they can be linked [6]. Elevated body weight is associated with oxidative damage, inflammatory responses, and lipid irregularities, factors that contribute to AMD progression [7, 8]. Research suggests that higher body fat may interfere with the transport of carotenoids to the macula, reducing macular pigment levels [9, 10]. Twenty years ago, researchers suggested that lipid accumulation is a contributing factor to the progression of AMD [11]. Some related studies reveals a connection between the formation of AMD and the lipid cholesterol metabolism, a relationship that was robustly substantiated through findings from the genome-wide association study (GWAS) [12]. Although obesity has been implicated with AMD in some Western populations, the exact mechanisms connecting obesity to AMD remain ambiguous [2]. Moreover, the impact of excess weight on the early versus late stages of AMD can differ [13].

Although BMI is a popular indicator of obesity, it is not a precise indicator of body fat distribution [14]. Most research has explored the link between obesity and AMD primarily through the lens of BMI. Certain research has found an association between BMI and the development of AMD, while others have not observed such a correlation [3]. Other studies have revealed a lack of apparent link between moderate-to-severe AMD and BMI. However, there were differences in the risk of moderate to severe macular edema between men and women and in WC [15]. WC is occasionally employed to estimate total body fat and provides a more focused evaluation of abdominal obesity [16, 17]. A significant number of individuals with a normal BMI exhibit abnormal levels of body fat [18]. Multiple anthropometric indices have been identified to evaluate body fat distribution, especially central obesity. Anthropometric indices include CI, BRI, VAI, WWI and WtHR [19]. These indices provide simple and effective ways to evaluate nutritional health and rapidly determine disease risk [20]. And they offer more nuanced views of body composition and fat distribution. They specifically capture visceral and abdominal fat, which have been linked to higher metabolic risk and chronic diseases, offering a more precise assessment of an individual’s health risks compared to BMI alone. These indices have been increasingly recognized as valuable tools in epidemiological research, as they better reflect the underlying biological mechanisms driving obesity-related diseases.

This article utilizes anthropometric measures to accurately assess whole-body lipid distribution and examine its impact on AMD in elderly Americans. We aimed to provide medical professionals and policymakers with tools to estimate AMD risk by exploring the relationship between various indices and AMD. This information could be used to inform targeted interventions for people at high risk, potentially contributing to a decrease in the incidence of AMD.

sec.title: Study Design and Sample sources
sec.p: The data of this article is original from the NHANES conducted between 2005 and 2008. The study was conducted as a cross-sectional analysis of American residents. Specific methods are publicly available and are accessible online. Eligibility criteria required participants to have complete data on weight, WC, BMI, triglycerides (TG), high-density lipoprotein cholesterol (HDL-C), AMD, and relevant covariates. This study used data from 5,602 people aged 50 years or older, with a survey period of 2005−2008. Of these, 1,479 participants without retinal photographs or with ungradable images, 258 without WWI, VAI, or BMI data, and 738 with incomplete covariate data were excluded. Ultimately, 3127 individuals took part in this research. (Fig. 1).

caption.p: Diagram of participants included in the analyses

sec.title: Outcome variables
sec.p: Forty-five-degree non-mydriatic digital retinal images were obtained from survey participants using the Canon CR6-45NM Non-Mydriatic Retinal Camera. Fundus images were analyzed at the University of Wisconsin-Madison following the modified Wisconsin Age-Related Maculopathy Grading Scheme. Early AMD was characterized by the presence of drusen or pigmentary changes, while late AMD was identified by features such as subretinal fibrous scarring, choroidal neovascularization, or geographic atrophy [21, 22]. When lesions exist in both eyes, the eye exhibiting the greater severity of AMD was selected for analysis. Each image was assessed by at least two trained graders, with an additional senior reviewer available to resolve any discrepancies.

sec.title: Definition of Novel Anthropometric Indices
sec.p: Trained health technicians collected physical measurements, include WC, height, body weight, TG, and HDL-C. Subsequent calculations of BMI, ABSI, BRI, VAI, CI, WWI, and WtHR were performed using established formulas as detailed below:

sec.title: Covariates
sec.p: The records of in-person interviews provided a comprehensive dataset encompassing demographic, lifestyle, and medical history information. The demographic variables considered were age, race, gender, education level (including five levels), and marital status (classified as married or unmarried).

Lifestyle variables included smoking and drinking. Classification of smoking based on blood cotinine was less than 0.015 ng/mL as low smoking, 0.015 to 3 ng/mL as moderate smoking and more than 3 ng/mL as high smoking. Individuals who do not consume alcohol, regardless of gender, were classified as non-drinkers. Individuals were classified as moderate drinkers if women reported consuming fewer than one alcoholic beverage per day and men indicated consumption of fewer than two beverages per day. Women who drink two to three drinks daily and men who consume three to four drinks were classified as heavy drinkers. Women who exceeded four alcoholic beverages per day and men who exceeded five beverages per day were categorized as excessive drinkers.

Medical data were derived from both physical examinations and self-reported questionnaires. In the NHANES questionnaire data, a participant was classified as having cardiovascular disease (CVD) if they reported a heart-related health issue. Diabetes was diagnosed if a physician diagnosed the participant using insulin or oral hypoglycemic medication, a fasting blood glucose level of 7.0 mmol/L or higher, or a glycosylated hemoglobin level of 6.5% or greater. Participants who have systolic blood pressure ≥ 130 mmHg or diastolic blood pressure ≥ 80 mmHg from three measurements, a history of hypertension, or use of antihypertensive drugs were diagnosed with hypertension. Cataract surgery history was based on self-report, following established diagnostic criteria from prior research. Due to the limited coverage and availability of cataract surgery in the United States, self-reported cataract surgery is a practical alternative indicator for clinically significant cataracts. Participants who have undergone cataract surgery were defined as having cataracts. The question assessed self-reported glaucoma prevalence, “Have you ever been informed by your ophthalmologist that you have glaucoma, sometimes referred to as ocular hypertension?” Participants who answered “yes” were classified as having glaucoma [22].

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: Given the detailed multi-stage probability sampling approach used by NHANES, all analyses accounted for sample weights, stratification, and clustering to address the complexity of the survey design. The characteristics of the participants are expressed as means with 95% confidence intervals (CI) for continuous variables and as percentages with 95% CI for categorical variables. All anthropometric measures were standardized by employing z-scores., calculated as follows: z-score = (index - mean) / SD [22]. Weighted multivariate regression analysis was utilized to investigate the complex interplay between anthropometric indices and AMD, including early and late stages. The results are presented as ORs along with their corresponding 95% CIs. Model 1 was without any adjustments; Model 2 was adjusted for gender, age, and race; and Model 3 included adjustments for gender, age, race, marital status, education, BMI, drinking, smoking, CVD, diabetes, hypertension, cataract surgery, and glaucoma.

To explore the associations between anthropometric indices and AMD, smooth curve fitting models were implemented. Additionally, a thorough subgroup analysis was performed to investigate the relationships between different anthropometric indices and AMD. This analysis utilized stratified multivariable logistic regression models, which allowed us to account for potential confounding factors within specific subgroups. The covariates included in these models were stratified according to relevant characteristics, such as age, gender, BMI, diabetes status, hypertension status, alcohol consumption, smoking habits, CVD, history of cataract surgery, and glaucoma status. A p-value below 0.05 was considered statistically significant. Statistical analyses were performed using R Studio (version 4.3.3) and EmpowerStats (version 4.1).

sec.title: General characteristics in Population
sec.p: Details of AMD characteristics are shown in Table 1. Of the 3,127 individuals, 2,825 (90.34%) were classified as having no AMD, while 302 (9.66%) showed any form of AMD. Specifically, 274 individuals (8.76%) had early AMD, while 28 (0.90%) were diagnosed with late AMD. The total prevalence of AMD in any form was 9.66%, with an average participant age of 71.248. Non-Hispanic White was the most common ethnicity (71.192%). Compared to the no AMD group, participants with AMD had higher indices of WT, CI, ABSI, and WWI (P < 0.05). However, gender, race, and education were not significantly different between the any AMD and without AMD groups (P > 0.05). Unmarried individuals exhibited a markedly elevated prevalence of AMD, particularly in the late stage (P < 0.05).

Regarding lifestyle factors, no substantial differences in drinking and smoking were identified across any of the stages of AMD (P > 0.05). Regarding health conditions, individuals with AMD were notably more likely to report a history of CVD and hypertension (P < 0.05). Additionally, more individuals with AMD had a history of cataract surgery or glaucoma (P < 0.05). There were no substantial variations in the prevalence of diabetes among the various stages of AMD (P > 0.05).

caption.p: The baseline characteristics of AMD status in the study population

sec.p: The characteristics of the participants are expressed as means with 95% CI for continuous variables and as percentages with 95% CI for categorical variables. P-value presented is based on the comparison between participants without AMD and those with any AMD.

sec.title: Association between the Anthropometric indices and AMD
sec.p: Table 2 provides a summary of the weighted logistic regression analysis results for any form of AMD. In unadjusted model 1, a higher ABSI Z-score (OR = 1.482 (1.306−1.681), P < 0.0001), CI Z-score (OR = 1.345 (1.182−1.531), P = 0.0001), and WWI Z-score (OR = 1.492(1.299−1.714), P < 0.0001) were associated with higher odds of any AMD. After full adjustment, the WtHR Z-score was markedly correlation with any AMD (OR = 1.237 (1.065−1.438), P = 0.0215). Additionally, the BRI Z-score revealed a significant association with any AMD (OR = 1.221(1.058−1.410), P = 0.0232). The CI Z-score maintained its significance (OR = 1.189 (1.039−1.362), P = 0.0334), and the WWI Z-score retained its association with any AMD (OR = 1.250 (1.095−1.425), P = 0.0090).

Subsequently, we investigated whether these anthropometric indices impacted the severity of AMD. The results of the association between anthropometric indices and early AMD are provided in STable 1. After full adjustment, the WtHR, BRI, CI, and WWI exhibited significant associations with early AMD (OR = 1.269 (1.089−1.479), P = 0.0138; OR = 1.251 (1.081−1.449), P = 0.0151; OR = 1.209 (1.045−1.399), P = 0.0310; and OR = 1.281 (1.116−1.471), P = 0.0064). As for late AMD (STable 2), all indices did not exhibit significant associations across models. These results suggest that these anthropometric indices (WtHR, BRI, CI, and WWI) can be important indicators for early AMD; however, their relevance is reduced for late AMD.

caption.p: Weighted logistic regression analysis showing the correlation between anthropometric indices and any AMD

sec.p: Weighted logistic regression analysis showing the correlation between anthropometric indices and any AMD. Model 1: unadjusted model. Model 2: adjusted for gender, age and race. Model 3: adjusted for gender, age, race, marital status, education, drinking, smoking, hypertension, diabetes, CVD, cataract operation and glaucoma.

sec.title: Subgroup analysis
sec.p: Fig. 2-5 shows the association between WtHR, CI, BRI, WWI, and AMD by stratified multivariate logistic regression analysis across various demographic and health-related subgroups, including gender, age, BMI, drinking, smoking, CVD, diabetes, hypertension, cataract operation, and glaucoma. There was a significant positive connection between WtHR and AMD in individuals who were overdrinking (P for interaction = 0.0033) and did not smoke (P for interaction = 0.0402). However, the correlation between WtHR and AMD did not vary significantly across age, gender, BMI, CVD, diabetes, hypertension, cataract surgery, and glaucoma subgroups (Fig. 2). Furthermore, CI, BRI, and WWI exhibited a significant positive correlation with AMD in participants with overdrinking (P for interaction = 0.0194, 0.0021, and 0.0022). The WWI and CI were significantly associated with AMD with females (P for the interaction = 0.0146 and 0.0117, respectively). In contrast, the BRI demonstrated a consistent relationship with AMD across both genders (Figs. 3−5). The relationships between CI, BRI, and WWI with AMD remained consistent across multiple subgroups, including divisions by age, BMI, smoking habits, drinking habits, presence of CVD, diabetes, hypertension, history of cataract surgery, and glaucoma.

caption.p: Subgroup analyses to determine the correlation of WtHR and AMD. Multivariable weight logistic analyses were conducted after adjusting for age, gender, BMI, drink, smoke, CVD, diabetes, hypertension, cataract operation, glaucoma

Subgroup analyses to determine the correlation of CI and AMD. Multivariable weight logistic analyses were conducted after adjusting for age, gender, BMI, drink, smoke, CVD, diabetes, hypertension, cataract operation, glaucoma

Subgroup analyses to determine the correlation of BRI and AMD. Multivariable weight logistic analyses were conducted after adjusting for age, gender, BMI, drink, smoke, CVD, diabetes, hypertension, cataract operation, glaucoma

Subgroup analyses to determine the correlation of WWI and AMD. Multivariable weight logistic analyses were conducted after adjusting for age, gender, BMI, drink, smoke, CVD, diabetes, hypertension, cataract operation, glaucoma

sec.title: Relationship between four anthropometric indices with AMD
sec.p: To illuminate the correlation between WtHR, CI, BRI, and WWI with AMD, smooth curve fitting model was employed. A two-segment linear regression model analysis revealed nonlinear associations for WtHR, BRI, and WWI with AMD (inflection points at 0.535, 4.045, and 12.065, respectively). CI exhibited a linear and positive correlation with AMD (Fig. 6).

caption.p: Smooth curve fitting models evaluated the correlation between four anthropometric indices with AMD. Adjusted smooth curve fitting models adjusted for gender, age, race, marital status, education, drinking, smoking, hypertension, diabetes, CVD, cataract operation, and glaucoma. The red line illustrates the smoothed curve that fits the data points, while the blue shaded areas indicate the 95% CI around the fit. (A) Smooth curve fitting model of WtHR. (B) Smooth curve fitting model of CI. (C) Smooth curve fitting model of BRI. (D) Smooth curve fitting model of WWI

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The NHANES cohort study from 2005 to 2008 investigated the associations between increased values of four anthropometric indices —WtHR, BRI, CI, and WWI— and the occurrence of AMD among U.S. citizens. The study findings revealed notable associations between elevated levels of these indices and increased AMD risk, enhancing our insight into the complex connections between anthropometric parameters and AMD. To date, this study provides strong positive evidence for WtHR, CI, BRI, and WWI with AMD. These indices were prominently associated with AMD in persons with heavy alcohol consumption. Additionally, WtHR was prominently associated with AMD in non-smokers. Additionally, WWI and CI exhibited stronger associations with AMD in females.

This study indicated that increasing WtHR, CI, BRI, and WWI were linked to the onset of early AMD. However, these four indices do not appear to influence the risk of late AMD. Part of the reason could be the small sample size of late AMD cases, while another possible reason could be as follows. Early AMD typically refers to pigmentary changes in the macula (yellow deposits beneath the retina) and retinal cells. These early symptoms are often associated with chronic inflammation and oxidative stress. Obesity plays a role in these processes by releasing proinflammatory cytokines, which are inflammatory mediators linked to the early stages of AMD because they can damage retinal cells, induce drusen formation, and contribute to oxidative stress [23]. In this study, late AMD is characterized by geographic atrophy, and the mechanisms leading to late AMD involve more complex and irreversible processes. Although inflammation remains a factor, the link between obesity and late AMD may not be as straightforward. Once macular degeneration reaches a certain threshold, the impact of obesity may be obscured by more severe pathological changes in the retina.

Elevated total systemic cholesterol levels during middle age can contribute to the progression of AMD. Cholesterol accumulation within Bruch’s membrane plays a key role in AMD pathogenesis, leading to the formation of basal linear deposits and drusen, which are hallmark features of the disorder [3, 24, 25]. Furthermore, increased body fat levels can limit carotenoids’ transit to the retina, lowering macular pigment levels and increasing AMD risk [9, 10].

Consequently, obesity is an important risk for AMD. Most studies use BMI and body weight as key measures of obesity. However, as muscle mass normally decreases with age, BMI cannot accurately represent obesity levels in the elderly [26]. Moreover, BMI and weight do not comprehensively evaluate body fat distribution [27]. To overcome these limitations, recent advancements in anthropometric indices have been implemented to conduct a more comprehensive analysis of obesity trends. These novel methods are designed to better distinguish between central obesity and the associated risk of AMD.

WtHR, and WC are widely considered biomarkers of central obesity. The advantages of WtHR include cost-effectiveness, safety of the model, ease of access, and substantial prediction in clinical settings. Several studies have demonstrated that WtHR outperforms other indicators in predicting cardiovascular diseases, diabetes, and hypertension [28, 29]. Currently, no research connects WtHR to AMD despite its established utility. In this study, individuals with higher WtHR indices showed an increased risk of early AMD. Additionally, WtHR maintains a positive correlation with AMD below the inflection point of 0.535.

BRI enables the assessment of both visceral and total body fat percentages [18]. BRI has demonstrated its reliability as a predictor of metabolic syndrome. Studies have indicated that increased BRI are independently linked with occurrences of diabetes. There is also no research establishing a connection between BRI and AMD, despite its proven utility. This study demonstrates a notable positive correlation between BRI with early AMD, with BRI exhibiting a positive relationship with AMD below the inflection point of 4.045.

CI has been used in the diagnosis of T2DM and hypertension. A study has demonstrated that CI can affect lipid levels [19]. Up to date, there is no research linking CI to AMD, even though its usefulness is well recognized. This study demonstrates a notable positive correlation between CI with early AMD, indicating that a higher CI is significantly linked to the development of early AMD. Besides, CI demonstrated a positive linear relationship with AMD.

WWI predominantly represents central obesity and can accurately diagnose excessive fat content combined with low muscle mass. Many studies suggest that WWI is linked with the development of hyperuricemia and other cardiovascular outcomes, including heart failure, left ventricular hypertrophy, and abdominal aortic calcification [30]. Increased body weight leads to oxidative damage, inflammatory processes, and lipid imbalances, each of which contributes to AMD development [7, 8]. This study demonstrates a notable positive correlation between BRI with early AMD. Furthermore, this study determined that below the inflection point of 12.065, WWI has a positive relationship with AMD.

Our study found no significant outcomes for ABSI and VAI. The reasons for this discrepancy are not completely understood, but the limitations of ABSI and VAI in effectively detecting AMD may contribute. Unlike these four measurements, ABSI does not adequately reflect the distribution of fat and muscle throughout the body. Its predictability may be limited by high clustering around the mean and low variability. In contrast, VAI focuses more on TG and L-HDL indices related to visceral adiposity and also fails to differentiate between fat and muscle mass.

This study identified a non-linear association between WtHR, BRI, and WWI with AMD, potentially influenced by various factors. First, the reduced sample size beyond certain thresholds may have affected the stability of the results, leading to a flattening or mild negative correlation between these indices and AMD. Additionally, fat accumulation may reach a saturation point, where its impact on AMD becomes negligible, with other biological mechanisms potentially driving the relationship [31]. As fat distribution rises, metabolic abnormalities may reach a peak, and factors such as vascular health and oxidative stress may become more significant contributors to AMD progression. Furthermore, as individuals age, other comorbidities (such as age and diet) may exert a stronger impact on AMD risk, potentially diminishing the influence of fat distribution on AMD [32].
These four indicators are associated with centripetal obesity and suggest that BMI cannot effectively describe the risk of developing AMD. Whole-body fat distribution is more relevant to AMD.

sec.title: Advantages and disadvantages
sec.p: The study has significant strengths and implications. First, the large sample size provides significant statistical power, increasing the reliability of the results. Second, smooth curve fitting allows for a comprehensive investigation of obesity prevalence rates and the associations between AMD and various measurement techniques. Third, our findings underscore the significant role of central adiposity in AMD, suggesting that WtHR, BRI, CI, and WWI could be early predictors of AMD.

However, it should be acknowledged that the study possesses certain potential limitations and considerations. Firstly, due to its cross-sectional design, the study is inherently unable to establish causal relationships. Furthermore, several biases and potential correlations may have influenced our findings, which have not been fully addressed in this study. Additionally, selection bias could be a concern as the NHANES dataset, while diverse and representative of the US population, may not fully capture all segments, particularly those who are underserved or harder to reach. This could lead to an incomplete or biased picture of health outcomes and associated factors.

One limitation of this study is its reliance on NHANES data from 2005 to 2008, during which the methods and diagnostic criteria for AMD were not as advanced as current standards, potentially affecting the accuracy of AMD classification. Additionally, the NHANES database excludes intermediate AMD, which may underestimate the true burden of the disease and hinder understanding of AMD progression and risk factors. Furthermore, the limited sample size of late AMD cases within the database may compromise the reliability of conclusions drawn from the data. These factors underscore the need for more comprehensive AMD classifications and larger, more up-to-date datasets to accurately assess the burden, progression, and risk factors associated with AMD.

These indices offer superior insights into body fat distribution compared to traditional measures, but their complexity in measurement and calculation may hinder widespread clinical adoption. Future efforts should aim to simplify these indices while maintaining their clinical relevance. As such, future research and development should focus on simplifying these indices while preserving their accuracy and clinical relevance, to facilitate their practical use in everyday healthcare settings.

To address this, future research should incorporate more recent data and updated diagnostic protocols to validate and expand upon our findings. Despite this limitation, our study provides valuable insights that could guide future investigations into the relationship between physical measurement indicators and AMD.

In summary, although this study offers important insights, acknowledging these limitations and potential biases is essential. Future research should address these issues to enhance the applicability and robustness of the findings.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Within the context of the study, an increase in the WtHR, BRI, and WWI indices was found to have a nonlinear positive association with AMD prevalence in U.S. adults aged 50 and older. Conversely, increases in the CI index showed a linear and positive association with AMD prevalence within this group. Physicians may recommend adopting a healthy lifestyle for patients with a normal BMI but elevated WtHR, BRI, CI, and WWI. This may include adopting a balanced diet and increasing physical activity, managing weight, and lowering blood lipid levels. While these interventions may help decrease AMD risk, the study has not conclusively shown that they definitely do so.
